20101221170106.000|20101221170109.000|TR0|It is the 22nd anniversary of the bombing 
20101221170109.000|20101221170111.000|TR0|over Lockerbie, Scotland.  Two hundred

20101221170114.000|20101221170116.000|TR0|attack, most of them Americans.

20101221170124.000|20101221170126.000|TR0|more than three months to live.  He is 
20101221170126.000|20101221170129.000|TR0|still alive in Libya.

20101221170131.000|20101221170134.000|TR0|Let's begin this hour with a brand new 
20101221170134.000|20101221170136.000|TR0|snapshot of America.  The 2010 Census 
20101221170136.000|20101221170139.000|TR0|results are now in.  They show the 
20101221170139.000|20101221170141.000|TR0|population of the United States, as of 
20101221170141.000|20101221170144.000|TR0|April 1st, 308,745,538.
20101221170144.000|20101221170146.000|TR0|
20101221170146.000|20101221170149.000|TR0|Twelve House seats in Congress will shift.
20101221170149.000|20101221170151.000|TR0|

20101221170216.000|20101221170219.000|TR0|beginning in 2012, which is a big year for 
20101221170219.000|20101221170221.000|TR0|the House of Representatives, but also the

20101221170226.000|20101221170229.000|TR0|And generally, let me just say this -- the 
20101221170229.000|20101221170231.000|TR0|states that are losing seats, they tend to 
20101221170231.000|20101221170234.000|TR0|be in the Northeast, in the Midwest.  They 
20101221170234.000|20101221170236.000|TR0|tend to be states that Barack Obama 
20101221170236.000|20101221170239.000|TR0|carried and the Democrats do well in.
20101221170239.000|20101221170241.000|TR0|
20101221170241.000|20101221170244.000|TR0|The states gaining seats, they tend to be 
20101221170244.000|20101221170246.000|TR0|in the South and in the Sun Belt area.  
20101221170246.000|20101221170249.000|TR0|And they have more often than not been

20101221170259.000|20101221170301.000|TR0|gain more than one, of course.  Eight 
20101221170301.000|20101221170304.000|TR0|states gain. President Obama carried only 
20101221170304.000|20101221170306.000|TR0|three of those states.
20101221170306.000|20101221170309.000|TR0|

20101221170311.000|20101221170314.000|TR0|those 10.  So you can see, the states

20101221170319.000|20101221170321.000|TR0|

20101221171001.000|20101221171003.000|TR0|
20101221171003.000|20101221171006.000|TR0|HARRIS:  A new nuclear arms treaty with 
20101221171006.000|20101221171008.000|TR0|Russia is close to a crucial procedural 
20101221171008.000|20101221171011.000|TR0|vote in the Senate.  The START treaty 
20101221171011.000|20101221171013.000|TR0|would reduce warheads from 2,200 to 1,550, 
20101221171013.000|20101221171016.000|TR0|re-establish onsite weapons inspections, 
20101221171016.000|20101221171018.000|TR0|and limit the number nuclear missile 
20101221171018.000|20101221171021.000|TR0|launchers to 700.
20101221171021.000|20101221171023.000|TR0|
20101221171023.000|20101221171026.000|TR0|Senior Congressional Correspondent Dana 
20101221171026.000|20101221171028.000|TR0|Bash is counting the votes on Capitol Hill.

20101221171041.000|20101221171043.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  They are, by our account, 
20101221171043.000|20101221171046.000|TR0|Tony.  As we first reported to you in the 
20101221171046.000|20101221171048.000|TR0|last hour, we are counting nine Republican 
20101221171048.000|20101221171051.000|TR0|senators.  That is the magic number, Tony, 
20101221171051.000|20101221171053.000|TR0|that the White House needs to get to the 
20101221171053.000|20101221171056.000|TR0|two-thirds majority.

20101221171101.000|20101221171103.000|TR0|about -- Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.  He 
20101221171103.000|20101221171106.000|TR0|made a public statement earlier today.  
20101221171106.000|20101221171108.000|TR0|Richard Lugar, Olympia Snowe, Susan 
20101221171108.000|20101221171111.000|TR0|Collins, they have been out there for a 
20101221171111.000|20101221171113.000|TR0|while.  Johnny Isakson put out a public 
20101221171113.000|20101221171116.000|TR0|statement.  He's from Georgia.
20101221171116.000|20101221171118.000|TR0|
20101221171118.000|20101221171121.000|TR0|Scott Brown, George Voinovich and Bob 
20101221171121.000|20101221171123.000|TR0|Bennett and Bob Corker -- those two 
20101221171123.000|20101221171126.000|TR0|senators told me in the hallway, actually, 
20101221171126.000|20101221171128.000|TR0|that they are going to be a "yes."  In 
20101221171128.000|20101221171131.000|TR0|fact, if you look at the Senate floor 
20101221171131.000|20101221171133.000|TR0|right now, Tony, Bob Corker is actually

20101221171148.000|20101221171151.000|TR0|play, Tony. I n fact, I've got to tell you

20101221171153.000|20101221171156.000|TR0|

20101221171231.000|20101221171233.000|TR0|vote to be tomorrow.       HARRIS:  Man,

20101221171738.000|20101221171740.000|TR0|
20101221171740.000|20101221171743.000|TR0|HARRIS:  A big vote in Washington today 
20101221171743.000|20101221171745.000|TR0|could dramatically change the future of 
20101221171745.000|20101221171748.000|TR0|the Internet.  The FCC is taking a vote on 
20101221171748.000|20101221171750.000|TR0|net neutrality.
20101221171750.000|20101221171753.000|TR0|
20101221171753.000|20101221171755.000|TR0|What does it mean for all of us?
20101221171755.000|20101221171758.000|TR0|
20101221171758.000|20101221171800.000|TR0|Josh is here to explain.
20101221171800.000|20101221171803.000|TR0|
20101221171803.000|20101221171805.000|TR0|Good to see you, Josh.
20101221171805.000|20101221171808.000|TR0|
20101221171808.000|20101221171810.000|TR0|JOSH LEVS, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  Hey there, 
20101221171810.000|20101221171813.000|TR0|Tony.
20101221171813.000|20101221171815.000|TR0|
20101221171815.000|20101221171818.000|TR0|It's the kind of thing people talk about a 
20101221171818.000|20101221171820.000|TR0|lot.  Most people don't understand the 
20101221171820.000|20101221171823.000|TR0|idea.
20101221171823.000|20101221171825.000|TR0|
20101221171825.000|20101221171828.000|TR0|The basic idea behind net neutrality is 
20101221171828.000|20101221171830.000|TR0|that everyone should have equal access to 
20101221171830.000|20101221171833.000|TR0|the Web.  That whether you're a huge 
20101221171833.000|20101221171835.000|TR0|company or a small independent operator, 
20101221171835.000|20101221171838.000|TR0|you should have equal access and speed on 
20101221171838.000|20101221171840.000|TR0|the Internet.  And the FCC says its rules 
20101221171840.000|20101221171843.000|TR0|would require that high- speed Internet 
20101221171843.000|20101221171845.000|TR0|providers treat everybody -- all these 
20101221171845.000|20101221171848.000|TR0|providers -- equally.
20101221171848.000|20101221171850.000|TR0|
20101221171850.000|20101221171853.000|TR0|Think of it as a road.  We've got a little 
20101221171853.000|20101221171855.000|TR0|picture for you here. Think of it like 
20101221171855.000|20101221171858.000|TR0|this road.  All right?       Right now 
20101221171858.000|20101221171900.000|TR0|everyone can get on the road and use those 
20101221171900.000|20101221171903.000|TR0|high-speed lanes.  But if the people who 
20101221171903.000|20101221171905.000|TR0|control the roads started allowing big 
20101221171905.000|20101221171908.000|TR0|companies to pay to use the faster lanes, 
20101221171908.000|20101221171910.000|TR0|while the smaller operators had to use the 
20101221171910.000|20101221171913.000|TR0|slower lanes, that could damage business 
20101221171913.000|20101221171915.000|TR0|opportunities for those smaller operators. 
20101221171915.000|20101221171918.000|TR0| It would make them harder to compete.
20101221171918.000|20101221171920.000|TR0|
20101221171920.000|20101221171923.000|TR0|Consumers don't like sitting around 
20101221171923.000|20101221171925.000|TR0|waiting for information. They want 
20101221171925.000|20101221171928.000|TR0|whatever is fastest.  And if the big guys 
20101221171928.000|20101221171930.000|TR0|are faster, they're going to be doing 
20101221171930.000|20101221171933.000|TR0|better.
20101221171933.000|20101221171935.000|TR0|
20101221171935.000|20101221171938.000|TR0|Now, the FCC's proposal is facing 
20101221171938.000|20101221171940.000|TR0|criticism from two different angles here.  
20101221171940.000|20101221171943.000|TR0|First, you have some Internet freedom 
20101221171943.000|20101221171945.000|TR0|advocates who says it actually doesn't go 
20101221171945.000|20101221171948.000|TR0|far enough.  One of their complaints is 
20101221171948.000|20101221171950.000|TR0|that it's not creating the same set of 
20101221171950.000|20101221171953.000|TR0|rules for mobile communication devices 
20101221171953.000|20101221171955.000|TR0|like your smartphone.
20101221171955.000|20101221171958.000|TR0|
20101221171958.000|20101221172000.000|TR0|Here was Senator Al Franken complaining 
20101221172000.000|20101221172003.000|TR0|about that on the Senate floor.
20101221172003.000|20101221172005.000|TR0|
20101221172005.000|20101221172008.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)
20101221172008.000|20101221172010.000|TR0|
20101221172010.000|20101221172013.000|TR0|SEN. AL FRANKEN (D), MINNESOTA:  Maybe you 
20101221172013.000|20101221172015.000|TR0|like Google Maps. Well, tough.  If the FCC 
20101221172015.000|20101221172018.000|TR0|passes this weak rule, Verizon will be 
20101221172018.000|20101221172020.000|TR0|able to cut off access to Google Maps, to 
20101221172020.000|20101221172023.000|TR0|the Google Maps app on your phone, and 
20101221172023.000|20101221172025.000|TR0|force you to use their own mapping 
20101221172025.000|20101221172028.000|TR0|program, Verizon Navigator, even if it is 
20101221172028.000|20101221172030.000|TR0|not as good, even if they charge money, 
20101221172030.000|20101221172033.000|TR0|and Google Maps is free.
20101221172033.000|20101221172035.000|TR0|
20101221172035.000|20101221172038.000|TR0|(END VIDEO CLIP)
20101221172038.000|20101221172040.000|TR0|
20101221172040.000|20101221172043.000|TR0|LEVS:  That was him complaining over the 
20101221172043.000|20101221172045.000|TR0|weekend there.
20101221172045.000|20101221172048.000|TR0|
20101221172048.000|20101221172050.000|TR0|Now, there's also people on the other side 
20101221172050.000|20101221172053.000|TR0|who say that government just shouldn't be 
20101221172053.000|20101221172055.000|TR0|getting involved here.  Here's an example.
20101221172055.000|20101221172058.000|TR0|
20101221172058.000|20101221172100.000|TR0|Robert M. McDowell, one of two Republican 
20101221172100.000|20101221172103.000|TR0|commissioners on the five-member 
20101221172103.000|20101221172105.000|TR0|commission of the FCC, he wrote this in a 
20101221172105.000|20101221172108.000|TR0|"Wall Street Journal" editorial.  He 
20101221172108.000|20101221172110.000|TR0|wrote, "Analysts and broadband companies 
20101221172110.000|20101221172113.000|TR0|of all sizes have told the FCC that new 
20101221172113.000|20101221172115.000|TR0|rules are likely to have the perverse 
20101221172115.000|20101221172118.000|TR0|effect of inhibiting capital investment, 
20101221172118.000|20101221172120.000|TR0|deterring innovation, raising operating 
20101221172120.000|20101221172123.000|TR0|costs, and ultimately increasing consumer 
20101221172123.000|20101221172125.000|TR0|prices."
20101221172125.000|20101221172128.000|TR0|
20101221172128.000|20101221172130.000|TR0|So, Tony, the debate is raging on right 
20101221172130.000|20101221172133.000|TR0|after that vote there at the FCC today.
20101221172133.000|20101221172135.000|TR0|
20101221172135.000|20101221172138.000|TR0|HARRIS:  Well, is it expected to pass, 
20101221172138.000|20101221172140.000|TR0|Josh?
20101221172140.000|20101221172143.000|TR0|
20101221172143.000|20101221172145.000|TR0|LEVS:  It actually is.  The expectation is 
20101221172145.000|20101221172148.000|TR0|that these net neutrality rules will pass. 
20101221172148.000|20101221172150.000|TR0| And then there are expected to be court 
20101221172150.000|20101221172153.000|TR0|challenges to what passes.
20101221172153.000|20101221172155.000|TR0|
20101221172155.000|20101221172158.000|TR0|We want to hear from you.  We're talking 
20101221172158.000|20101221172200.000|TR0|about it on Facebook and Twitter today.  
20101221172200.000|20101221172203.000|TR0|I'm at JoshLevsCNN.  Go ahead, weigh in, 
20101221172203.000|20101221172205.000|TR0|your thoughts on net neutrality -- Tony.   
20101221172205.000|20101221172208.000|TR0|    HARRIS:  Terrific stuff.  All right, 
20101221172208.000|20101221172210.000|TR0|Josh.  Thank you.
20101221172210.000|20101221172213.000|TR0|
20101221172213.000|20101221172215.000|TR0|LEVS:  You got it.
20101221172215.000|20101221172218.000|TR0|
20101221172218.000|20101221172220.000|TR0|HARRIS:  Boy, the weather is really 
20101221172220.000|20101221172222.000|TR0|complicated.  Really complicated in most 
20101221172222.000|20101221172225.000|TR0|of the country right now, and it certainly 
20101221172225.000|20101221172227.000|TR0|making your travel plans difficult to 
20101221172227.000|20101221172230.000|TR0|maneuver and to finalize.

20101221172252.000|20101221172255.000|TR0|
20101221172255.000|20101221172257.000|TR0|HARRIS:  If you think the weather is bad 
20101221172257.000|20101221172300.000|TR0|here, check out Western Europe.  It is 
20101221172300.000|20101221172302.000|TR0|socked in by one of the worst snowstorms 
20101221172302.000|20101221172305.000|TR0|in decades. Few people going anywhere

20101221173019.000|20101221173022.000|TR0|LATINO ELECTED AND APPOINTED OFFICIALS:

20101221173024.000|20101221173027.000|TR0|What's interesting about the states that 
20101221173027.000|20101221173029.000|TR0|have gained congressional seats is that 
20101221173029.000|20101221173032.000|TR0|Latino growth in those states have fueled 
20101221173032.000|20101221173034.000|TR0|the population increase in those states.  
20101221173034.000|20101221173037.000|TR0|That means that Latinos are reshaping the 
20101221173037.000|20101221173039.000|TR0|political geography of states such as 
20101221173039.000|20101221173042.000|TR0|Texas, such as Florida, such as Arizona, 
20101221173042.000|20101221173044.000|TR0|such as Nevada, even states in the Deep 
20101221173044.000|20101221173047.000|TR0|South, such as South Carolina or Georgia.
20101221173047.000|20101221173049.000|TR0|
20101221173049.000|20101221173052.000|TR0|So, if you want to understand the 
20101221173052.000|20101221173054.000|TR0|political future of these states you need

20101221173057.000|20101221173059.000|TR0|have had Latino population growth

20101221173159.000|20101221173202.000|TR0|And I think her analysis was excellent, 
20101221173202.000|20101221173204.000|TR0|Tony, for the generational growth of the 
20101221173204.000|20101221173207.000|TR0|Latino power in our politics.
20101221173207.000|20101221173209.000|TR0|
20101221173209.000|20101221173212.000|TR0|The question is, what happens in the short 
20101221173212.000|20101221173214.000|TR0|term?  This is why the most recent 
20101221173214.000|20101221173217.000|TR0|election is so important.  When you go 
20101221173217.000|20101221173219.000|TR0|through the states that gain seats, 
20101221173219.000|20101221173222.000|TR0|Arizona gains one, Florida gains two, 
20101221173222.000|20101221173224.000|TR0|Texas gains four, Nevada gains one, South 
20101221173224.000|20101221173227.000|TR0|Carolina gains one, Utah gains one, 
20101221173227.000|20101221173229.000|TR0|Washington state gains one.  Only one of 
20101221173229.000|20101221173232.000|TR0|those states has a Democratic governor.  
20101221173232.000|20101221173234.000|TR0|Because the Republicans did so well in the 
20101221173234.000|20101221173237.000|TR0|midterm elections, the Republicans will 
20101221173237.000|20101221173239.000|TR0|dominate the redistricting process in most 
20101221173239.000|20101221173242.000|TR0|of these states that are gaining seats.
20101221173242.000|20101221173244.000|TR0|
20101221173244.000|20101221173247.000|TR0|And in a lot of the states that are losing 
20101221173247.000|20101221173249.000|TR0|seats as well because of Republican gains. 
20101221173249.000|20101221173252.000|TR0| The new Republican governor in Ohio, 
20101221173252.000|20101221173254.000|TR0|Republican governor in Pennsylvania, 
20101221173254.000|20101221173257.000|TR0|Republican governor in Michigan.  So, the 
20101221173257.000|20101221173259.000|TR0|Republicans have so much influence now in 
20101221173259.000|20101221173302.000|TR0|redrawing the lines in the short term, the 
20101221173302.000|20101221173304.000|TR0|process should work, could work, to their 
20101221173304.000|20101221173307.000|TR0|political advantage.
20101221173307.000|20101221173309.000|TR0|
20101221173309.000|20101221173312.000|TR0|To the longer term generationally, the 
20101221173312.000|20101221173314.000|TR0|growth of Latino political power, Roslyn 
20101221173314.000|20101221173317.000|TR0|is exactly right.  Barack Obama would not 
20101221173317.000|20101221173319.000|TR0|be president if it were not for the Latino 
20101221173319.000|20101221173322.000|TR0|population in Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico 
20101221173322.000|20101221173324.000|TR0|that he helped ride to victory in 2008.  
20101221173324.000|20101221173327.000|TR0|The question is, what happens in the short 
20101221173327.000|20101221173329.000|TR0|term in the big political fights over 
20101221173329.000|20101221173332.000|TR0|redrawing all those lines?
20101221173332.000|20101221173334.000|TR0|
20101221173334.000|20101221173337.000|TR0|HARRIS:  Roslyn, let me flip John's 
20101221173337.000|20101221173339.000|TR0|analysis a bit with this question.  Are 
20101221173339.000|20101221173342.000|TR0|you worried legislatures, say, in Florida, 
20101221173342.000|20101221173344.000|TR0|in Texas, will realign districts to 
20101221173344.000|20101221173347.000|TR0|minimize Latino political power?
20101221173347.000|20101221173349.000|TR0|
20101221173349.000|20101221173352.000|TR0|GOLD:  Well, you know, that's always a 
20101221173352.000|20101221173354.000|TR0|concern in the redistricting process.  
20101221173354.000|20101221173357.000|TR0|That both parties are going to seek 
20101221173357.000|20101221173359.000|TR0|political gain.  But federal law requires 
20101221173359.000|20101221173402.000|TR0|that there not be discrimination against 
20101221173402.000|20101221173404.000|TR0|Latinos and other underrepresented groups 
20101221173404.000|20101221173407.000|TR0|during the redistricting process.  So, 
20101221173407.000|20101221173409.000|TR0|what that means is no matter who draws the 
20101221173409.000|20101221173412.000|TR0|line, they have to ensure that Latinos 
20101221173412.000|20101221173414.000|TR0|have an opportunity to elect their

20101221174324.000|20101221174326.000|TR0|rating. If she doesn't want to report her 
20101221174326.000|20101221174329.000|TR0|mom to the police and file a report, which 
20101221174329.000|20101221174331.000|TR0|is really what you would need to do in 
20101221174331.000|20101221174334.000|TR0|order to make sure that that could 
20101221174334.000|20101221174336.000|TR0|potential be disputed and deleted from her 
20101221174336.000|20101221174339.000|TR0|credit report, at the very least she needs 
20101221174339.000|20101221174341.000|TR0|to set up credit alerts on her credit 
20101221174341.000|20101221174344.000|TR0|reports with the three credit bureaus. 
20101221174344.000|20101221174346.000|TR0|With Equifax, Experian and Transunion. She 
20101221174346.000|20101221174349.000|TR0|should put a statement on her credit 
20101221174349.000|20101221174351.000|TR0|report saying, I've been the victim of 
20101221174351.000|20101221174354.000|TR0|identity theft. Most times, however, 
20101221174354.000|20101221174356.000|TR0|they're going to want to see a police 
20101221174356.000|20101221174359.000|TR0|report. So even if you can just file the 
20101221174359.000|20101221174401.000|TR0|report but not necessarily report the mom, 
20101221174401.000|20101221174404.000|TR0|who should be reported, by the way, but I 
20101221174404.000|20101221174406.000|TR0|understand that people just don't want to 
20101221174406.000|20101221174409.000|TR0|do that. This is a very common act, 
20101221174409.000|20101221174411.000|TR0|believe it or not. It's sad and true.
20101221174411.000|20101221174414.000|TR0|
20101221174414.000|20101221174416.000|TR0|ELAM: And she's actually an adult child, 
20101221174416.000|20101221174419.000|TR0|too. She's 22. So there's not a lot dad 
20101221174419.000|20101221174421.000|TR0|can to. So it's good to keep in mind.
20101221174421.000|20101221174424.000|TR0|
